head.title: Pd Nanocluster/Monolayer MoS2 Heterojunctions for Light-Induced Room-Temperature Hydrogen Sensing | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Pd Nanocluster/Monolayer MoS2 Heterojunctions for Light-Induced Room-Temperature Hydrogen Sensing

Developing sensing approaches that can exploit visible light for the detection of low-concentration hydrogen at room temperatures has become increasingly important for the safe use of hydrogen in many applications. In this study, heterostructures composed of monolayer MoS2 and Pd nanoclusters (Pd/MoS2) acting as photo- and hydrogen-sensitizers are successfully fabricated in a facile and scalable manner. The uniform deposition of morphologically isotropic Pd nanoclusters (11.5 ± 2.2 nm) on monolayer MoS2 produces a plethora of active heterojunctions, effectively suppressing charge carrier recombination under light illumination. The dual photo- and hydrogen-sensitizing functionality of Pd/MoS2 can enable its use as an active sensing layer in optoelectronic hydrogen sensors. Gas-sensing examinations reveal that the sensing performance of Pd/MoS2 is enhanced three-fold under visible light illumination (17% for 140 ppm of H2) in comparison with dark light (5% for 140 ppm of H2). Photoactivation is also found to enable excellent sensing reversibility and reproducibility in the obtained sensor. As a proof-of-concept, the integration of Pd nanoclusters and monolayer MoS2 can open a new avenue for light-induced hydrogen gas sensing at room temperature.

div.p:
Developing sensing approaches that can exploit visible light for the detection of low-concentration hydrogen at room temperatures has become increasingly important for the safe use of hydrogen in many applications. In this study, heterostructures composed of monolayer MoS
2
and Pd nanoclusters (Pd/MoS
2
) acting as photo- and hydrogen-sensitizers are successfully fabricated in a facile and scalable manner. The uniform deposition of morphologically isotropic Pd nanoclusters (11.5 ± 2.2 nm) on monolayer MoS
2
produces a plethora of active heterojunctions, effectively suppressing charge carrier recombination under light illumination. The dual photo- and hydrogen-sensitizing functionality of Pd/MoS
2
can enable its use as an active sensing layer in optoelectronic hydrogen sensors. Gas-sensing examinations reveal that the sensing performance of Pd/MoS
2
is enhanced three-fold under visible light illumination (17% for 140 ppm of H
2
) in comparison with dark light (5% for 140 ppm of H
2
). Photoactivation is also found to enable excellent sensing reversibility and reproducibility in the obtained sensor. As a proof-of-concept, the integration of Pd nanoclusters and monolayer MoS
2
can open a new avenue for light-induced hydrogen gas sensing at room temperature.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Hydrogen is considered as a future energy source due to its abundance, eco-friendliness, and intrinsic high energy density.
(1)
However, hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, and highly explosive gas. This makes hydrogen detection at low concentrations extremely important, particularly for safe utility in industrial processing, hydrogen storage, and separation.
(2,3)
Chemiresistive sensors using traditional metal oxide semiconducting materials (e.g., SnO
2
, WO
3
, ZnO, and NiO)
(4−7)
as the active sensing layer have been used for hydrogen detection because of their chemical stability, high reproducibility, and simple operation. However, these sensors only show satisfactory performance at elevated temperatures (150 to 400 °C), which is accompanied by high power consumption, background drift, and safety concerns for detecting flammable and explosive gases. Developing sensing systems workable at room temperatures is therefore extremely important, yet it remains a challenging task due to the practical issues of room-temperature gas sensors, including low sensitivity, sluggish response behavior, and incomplete recovery. In this circumstance, photoinduced chemiresistive or optoelectric sensing appears to be a feasible approach to overcome the aforementioned issues. Under light illumination, the optically generated charge carriers can modulate the background resistance and/or actively promote rapid solid–gas chemisorption on the surface of a given sensor.
(8−11)
In connection to this aspect, a rational combination of two or more components with distinctive properties (i.e., photo- and hydrogen-sensitization) into a heterostructure can enable their use in optoelectric sensors that can efficiently exploit light for hydrogen detection. Additionally, the interfacial surfaces and complex electronic interactions between two components in heterostructures often account for a more pronounced sensing performance relative to those of their separated counterparts.
(12)

Recently, two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), in particular MoS
2
, have been simulated in gas-sensing applications because of their tunable bandgap, layer-dependent semiconducting behavior, and structural defect manipulation.
(13,14)
Interestingly, the monolayer sheets, unlike bulk MoS
2
with an indirect bandgap of ∼1.2 eV, possess a direct bandgap of approximately 1.8 eV. The unique semiconducting behavior is thus important for the facile fabrication of visible light photosensitizers in optoelectronic sensors because the bandgap of monolayer MoS
2
falls within the spectrum of solar/indoor light. However, these 2D materials have several limitations regarding low selectivity or long recovery time due to a strong binding between the material surface with targeted gas molecules,
(15)
and high operating temperatures are usually required to improve the sensing recovery. Another strategy to overcome these issues is by rationally functionalizing or heterostructuring 2D materials with hydrogen-sensitizing species, for example, metal nanocrystals,
(16,17)
to enable the formation of heterostructures with improved sensing performance. Also, a rational design of Schottky contacts formed between metal and 2D materials can be a new avenue for a variety of applications.
(18)
For the hydrogen-sensitizing part, palladium (Pd) is very promising because of its selective and reversible interaction with H
2
molecules to form palladium hydride (PdH
x
). Nanostructured Pd can also enhance the sensing performance by promoting the dissociation of H
2
molecules into H atoms (also known as spillover effect) or by shortening the diffusion pathway of H atoms within PdH
x
by decreasing the size of the Pd species. However, the exclusive use of pristine Pd as a hydrogen-sensing layer leads to several practical issues. For instance, typical Pd-based hydrogen sensors usually employ Pd wires or arrays to form an electrically closed circuit with interdigitated layers and to record electrical sensing signals upon gas exposure. However, fabrication processes for such anisotropic topologies are rather expensive and complicated, hindering their practical application and commercialization. In addition, the reversible hydrogen-induced lattice expansion (HILE) of Pd during hydrogen exposure can inevitably cause electrical contact loss of Pd structures and deteriorate their sensing capability. On this basis, the rational immobilization of Pd nanostructures onto predesigned semiconducting MoS
2
can be helpful for enabling the dual photo and hydrogen-sensitizing properties of the obtained heterostructures as well as preventing undesired contact loss throughout the sensing operation.

Recently, our group has successfully developed a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique for the growth of highly crystalline, continuous monolayer MoS
2
.
(19,20)
The high quality and large surface-to-volume ratio of MoS
2
allowed the facile deposition of isotropic Pd nanoclusters onto the monolayer MoS
2
surface to form Pd/MoS
2
heterostructures. In situ Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and photoluminescence (PL) clearly demonstrated that the interfacial heterojunctions between Pd nanoclusters and monolayer MoS
2
can improve the utilization of visible light by effectively suppressing charge carrier recombination under light illumination. The examination of hydrogen gas sensing revealed the visible light enhancement effect toward sensing performance, mainly stemming from the dual functionality of hydrogen and photosensitization in the Pd/MoS
2
heterostructures. The sensing reversibility and reproducibility were also improved by photoradiation. To our knowledge, this is the first example to demonstrate the heterostructuring of Pd nanoclusters and monolayer MoS
2
as a strategy to take advantage of light-induced hydrogen gas sensing at room temperature. Further discussion on the light-induced sensing mechanism will be presented herein.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Molybdenum trioxide (MoO
3
, Acros Organics), sulfur powder (S, Sigma-Aldrich), palladium(II) chloride (PdCl
2
, Sigma-Aldrich), aniline, poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA),
N
,
N
-dimethylformamide (DMF, Sigma-Aldrich), ethanol, and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were used as received. The Pd–aniline complex was prepared by mixing PdCl
2
(100 mg, 0.56 mmol) and aniline (20 mL, 210 mmol) in a 20 mL round-bottom flask at 50 °C for 5 h to yield a yellowish powder. Afterward, the obtained product was centrifuged (3000 rpm, 10 min) and purified by repeated rinsing with ethanol and acetone. The Pd content in the Pd–aniline complex determined using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was 29.1 wt %.

Single-layered MoS
2
synthesis was carried out in a two-zone CVD capable of having temperature control in both zones, with MoO
3
and S powders used as precursors.
(19)
S powder (0.18 g) and MoO
3
powder (0.3 mg) were placed in zone-1 (low-temperature) and zone-2 (high-temperature), respectively. A SiO
2
/Si wafer was placed upside down above MoO
3
. N
2
was used as the carrier gas. A pressure controller was positioned downstream of the CVD to monitor the chamber pressure. First, the chamber was filled with N
2
(200 sccm) until the pressure reached 300 Torr. Next, zone-1 and zone-2 were heated to 150 °C (15 °C/min) and 400 °C (40 °C/min) for 15 min, respectively. Afterward, the N
2
flow rate was set at 12 sccm, and the temperature was further increased to 400 °C for zone-1 (27 °C/min) and 850 °C for zone-2 (57 °C/min). A reaction time of 6 min was deemed to be optimal for the growth of monolayer MoS
2
on the SiO
2
/Si substrate.

For the synthesis of the Pd/MoS
2
heterojunction, the as-synthesized MoS
2
on a SiO
2
/Si wafer was immersed in a solution containing a Pd–aniline complex (1.0 mg), DMF (1.0 mL), and ethanol (1.5 mL) for 12 h. The Pd–aniline/MoS
2
sample was subsequently positioned in a quartz tube and heated to 350 °C for 30 min in H
2
:N
2
(10 sccm/90 sccm) to produce Pd/MoS
2
.

div.h3:
Transfer of Pd/MoS
2
onto Au Microfinger Electrode for Hydrogen Gas Sensing
div.div:
A PMMA film was spin-coated on the surface of Pd/MoS
2
on SiO
2
/Si at 2000 rpm for 30 s, followed by heating at 90 °C to protect the Pd/MoS
2
layer during etching processes. Subsequently, the sample was floated on 1 M KOH and heated at 90 °C to etch away SiO
2
. After detachment from the Si substrate, the PMMA-protected Pd/MoS
2
film was transferred to a deionized water bath and washed several times with ethanol. Next, the PMMA-protected Pd/MoS
2
film was scooped up and transferred onto the microfinger electrode. The protecting PMMA layer was finally removed by immersing the electrode in toluene for 12 h.

The morphologies of Pd/MoS
2
were imaged using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; Hitachi S-4300, U.S.A.) and field emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM; JEM-2100F, Japan). XPS measurements were performed on a K-Alpha spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, K-Alpha, U.S.A.) with monochromated Al Kα radiation as the X-ray source for excitation. Raman spectra were obtained using an X-plora Horiba spectrometer (Horiba Jobin-Yvon, France) with a 532 nm single longitudinal laser. ICP-OES measurements were carried out using an Optima 7300 DV (PerkinElmer, U.S.A.). Gas sensing measurements were carried within an enclosed chamber equipped with a Keithley 4200 semiconductor characterization system for monitoring resistance changes. Two mass-flow controllers (MFC, ATOVAC, GMC-1200) were used to achieve the desired H
2
concentration from 20 to 140 ppm by changing the flow-rate ratio between 1% H
2
and air. A solar simulator (Newport, 150 W xenon lamp) was used to illuminate the sensing devices. The distance between the light source and the sensors and the light intensity was fixed at 40 cm and 4 mW cm
–2
, respectively. All the gas sensing experiments were performed under the same condition with and without light illumination at 25 and 100 °C. The applied bias voltage was set at 3 V.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The synthesis protocol for the deposition of Pd nanoclusters on monolayer MoS
2
to produce Pd/MoS
2
heterostructures, which can be used for chemiresistive hydrogen gas sensing, is quite straightforward, as schematically illustrated in
Figure
1
a. Specifically, the as-grown CVD MoS
2
was initially wet-impregnated within a Pd–aniline solution, followed by thermal annealing in H
2
/N
2
gas at 350 °C for 30 min for the nucleation and growth of Pd nanoclusters on the basal surfaces of MoS
2
. Optical and SEM (
Figures
1
b and
S1
) images reveal that the CVD-grown MoS
2
mainly comprises a uniform and continuous film with a few separate microtriangles (∼50–90 μm) located at the edge of the film. The uniformity and continuity of the MoS
2
film allow its further use in the following gas-sensing experiments. HR-TEM and the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) (
Figure
1
c) confirm the single-crystalline hexagonal structure of MoS
2
. In addition, the lattice fringe of 0.27 nm can be assigned to the
d
-spacing of the (100) facet of the crystalline MoS
2
phase.
(21)
The monolayer structure of MoS
2
is further corroborated by the height profile extracted from atomic force microscopy (AFM) conducted at the edge site of the MoS
2
film. The transition from SiO
2
to MoS
2
is approximately 1 ± 2.2 nm, equivalent to the monolayer thickness of MoS
2
. The successful integration of pseudospherical Pd nanoclusters with the mean size of 12 ± 2.2 nm on the MoS
2
film can be clearly observed in the TEM image (
Figure
1
e). The topology and continuous nature of the MoS
2
film are well preserved after Pd deposition, as shown in the SEM images (
Figure S2
). The lattice fringe of 0.23 nm corresponding to the
d
-spacing of the (111) lattice planes in the crystalline face-centered cubic structure of Pd is observed in the HR-TEM image (
Figure
1
f).
(22,23)
Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping analysis (
Figure
1
g) shows that Mo and S are uniformly distributed throughout the investigated area, whereas Pd is centrally localized, further corroborating the formation of Pd nanoclusters on MoS
2
.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic illustration of the synthesis of Pd/MoS
2
heterostructures. (b–d) Characterizations of pristine MoS
2
: (b) optical image, (c) HR-TEM with FFT (inset in c), and (d) AFM and the corresponding height profile revealing the MoS
2
thickness of approximately 0.9 nm. (e–g) Characterizations of Pd/MoS
2
: (e) TEM and (f) HR-TEM images of a single Pd nanocluster. Inset in (e): high-magnification TEM image of a Pd nanocluster (top) and Pd size distribution (bottom). (g) Elemental mapping by EDX analysis showing Mo (red), S (green), and Pd (blue).

div.div:
High-resolution XPS was used to investigate the surface characteristics and elemental valence states of MoS
2
, Pd aniline-treated MoS
2
, and Pd/MoS
2
heterostructures. As observed in
Figure
2
a, the deconvoluted spectrum of the Mo 3d core level of the bare MoS
2
shows two major peaks at 230.5 and 233.6 eV corresponding to Mo
4+
3d
5/2
and Mo
4+
3d
3/2
, respectively.
(24)
For Pd aniline-treated MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
, the characteristic peaks of Mo
4+
collectively shift to a slightly lower binding energy by approximately 0.3 eV relative to those of the bare MoS
2
. The doublet of S
2–
2p
3/2
(163.4 eV) and S
2–
2p
1/2
(164.6 eV) in the bare MoS
2
exhibits a similar trend to that observed in the Mo 3d spectrum, shifting by 0.4 eV to a lower binding energy in Pd aniline-treated MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
(
Figure
2
b). The observed peak shifts in the Mo 3d and S 2p XPS profiles can be explained by a strong coordination bond between the Pd species (Pd
2+
or Pd
0
) and the exposed sulfur sites of MoS
2
upon Pd deposition. In addition to the MoS
2
characteristic peaks observed in the Mo 3d and S 2p, the peaks at 229.5 and 232.5 eV in Mo 3d and 162.4 and 164.0 eV in S 2p can be attributed to a small amount of the nonstoichiometric Mo
x
S
y
.
(25)
The successful immobilization of Pd precursors onto MoS
2
by wet-impregnation with a Pd–aniline solution is confirmed by the well-resolved peaks at 336.5 eV (Pd
2+
3d
5/2
) and 342 eV (Pd
2+
3d
3/2
) and peaks at 338.6 eV (Pd
4+
3d
5/2
) and 343.8 eV (Pd
4+
3d
3/2
) (
Figure
2
c).
(26−28)
The coexistence of Pd
2+
and Pd
4+
could be attributed to the partial oxidation of Pd salt during the preparation of Pd–aniline complex. The atomic ratio of S/Mo estimated from the XPS data for MoS
2
, Pd–aniline treated MoS
2
, and Pd/MoS
2
is 2.11, 2.08, and 1.94, respectively. Thermal annealing in H
2
/N
2
gas leads to an effective reduction of Pd
2+
to Pd
0
, as clearly evidenced by the evolution of two major peaks at 335.5 and 341 eV, corresponding to Pd
0
3d
5/2
and Pd
0
3d
3/2
, respectively.
(26,27,29)

div.p:
Figure 2. High-resolution XPS profiles of (a) Mo 3d, (b) S 2p, and (c) Pd 3d of bare MoS
2
(top), Pd–aniline-treated MoS
2
(mid), and Pd/MoS
2
(bottom)

div.div:
In general, the characteristic Raman modes of layered MoS
2
corresponding to the in-plane vibration E
1
2g
of S and Mo atoms and out-of-plane vibration A
1g
of S atoms (
Figure
3
a) are important for understanding the electron–phonon behavior in monolayer MoS
2
. The position shifting of the E
1
2g
and A
1g
peaks can be spatially correlated to the internal strain
(30−32)
or increasing/decreasing restoring forces of the S atoms caused by interlayer interactions.
(33)
Therefore, to examine the effect of Pd deposition on the structural properties of monolayer MoS
2
, in situ Raman mappings (10 × 10 μm) for E
1
2g
and A
1g
were obtained at the same location prior to and after immobilizing the Pd nanoclusters (
Figure
3
b,c). The peak separations (A
1g
–E
1
2g
) for the bare MoS
2
are in the range of 18–19 cm
–1
throughout the scan area (
Figure S3a
), which is highly consistent with the reported values of monolayer MoS
2
.
(34,35)
Although the A
1g
-E
1
2g
values for Pd/MoS
2
slightly increase by ∼1 cm
–1
, these values fall within an acceptable range of monolayer MoS
2
(
Figure S3b
), indicating that Pd deposition has an insignificant impact on the monolayer property of MoS
2
. Importantly, while the E
1
2g
modes in both samples (
Figure
3
d,e) are almost similar in their vibrational frequencies, the A
1g
of MoS
2
in Pd/MoS
2
shows a noticeable 2 cm
–1
upshift relative to that of the bare MoS
2
. This is presumably attributed to the enhanced restoring forces on the S atoms in the out-of-plane vibration mode caused by the deposition of Pd nanoclusters on the surface of MoS
2
.
(33)
These data are consistent with the observed peak shifts in the Mo 3d and S 2p XPS profiles of Pd/MoS
2
, suggesting an interaction between deposited Pd nanoclusters and MoS
2
.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Characteristic Mo–S bonding vibration in MoS
2
. Optical images of the (b) as-synthesized MoS
2
and (c) Pd/MoS
2
. In situ Raman position corresponding to E
1
2g
and A
1g
of the (d,f) as-synthesized MoS
2
and (e,g) Pd/MoS
2
.

div.div:
Figure
4
a shows the PL spectra of the bare MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
. MoS
2
exhibits a strong PL peak at 1.85 eV arising from the direct recombination of photogenerated electron–hole pair characteristic of monolayer MoS
2
.
(36,37)
However, the PL peak of MoS
2
is highly suppressed after Pd deposition, indicating that the formation of Pd/MoS
2
heterojunctions is beneficial for hindering the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers.
(38)
We also examined the valence band structures (Mo 4d) using XPS for MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
. The data are shown in
Figure S4
. As seen, the separation between the Fermi level and the valence band maximum (VBM) in MoS
2
is approximately 1.61 eV, which is higher than that in Pd/MoS
2
(0.95 eV), suggesting that the Fermi level moves relatively closer to the VBM in Pd/MoS
2
than in MoS
2
(
Figure S4a
). Combined with PL data (
Figure
4
a), the band diagram for MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
can be proposed as shown in
Figure S4b
, in which Pd/MoS
2
shows increasing p-type properties.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) PL spectra of the as-synthesized MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
heterostructure. (b) Schematic illustration of the hydrogen sensor constructed from the Pd/MoS
2
heterostructure. (c) Optical image showing the surface of the sensor surface before and after transfer. (d)
I
–
V
curve of the Pd/MoS
2
heterostructure under dark and light conditions. (e) Photoresponsivity of Pd/MoS
2
under chopped light.

div.div:
We also examined the photoresponsivity of Pd/MoS
2
by transferring the film onto a microfinger electrode, as schematically illustrated in
Figures
4
b and
S5a
. Optical images (
Figures
4
c and
S5b
) and Raman (
Figure S5c
) spectra reveal that the transfer process is successful with Pd/MoS
2
, which mainly sustains the film continuity and monolayer structures. The current–voltage (
I
–
V
) curves of MoS
2
and Pd/MoS
2
under dark condition are shown in
Figure S6
, revealing that MoS
2
shows a linear
I
–
V
curve, suggesting an ohmic contact between Au/MoS
2
/Au. However, the
I
–
V
curve observed in Pd/MoS
2
is nonlinear, indicating that there is a shift in the work function that leads to possible Schottky nature in Pd/MoS
2
heterojunction. The Schottky barrier formed can prevent the recombination of optically generated electron–hole pairs. In addition, the
I
–
V
curves of Pd/MoS
2
(
Figure
4
d) clearly demonstrates an increase in current after visible light illumination at room temperature. The photoresponsivity of Pd/MoS
2
under chopped light illumination at an applied bias of 3 V in
Figure
4
e shows that the generation of optically excited carriers leads to a considerable decrease in the background resistance. These data suggest that the heterojunctions comprising Pd nanoclusters and monolayer MoS
2
can efficiently improve the utilization of visible light to generate more charge carriers and reduce the background noise, which are favorable for visible light-enhanced chemiresistive gas sensors. Based on these results, the hydrogen gas-sensing performances of the Pd/MoS
2
heterojunctions were examined under visible light illumination. The gas-sensing response (%) is defined in terms of the resistance ratio as shown in
eq 1
(1)
where
R
g
and
R
0
are the resistances in hydrogen ambient and in air, respectively.

Figures
5
a and
S7
shows the typical sensing response curves and actual resistance versus time of Pd/MoS
2
at 25 °C toward 20–140 ppm hydrogen gas with and without visible light illumination. In dark light, Pd/MoS
2
shows poor performance or even remains irresponsive upon exposure to hydrogen concentrations lower than 60 ppm. However, it is interesting to note that the sensing performance of Pd/MoS
2
upon light illumination is drastically enhanced, as indicated by the responsivity increase with increasing hydrogen concentration, ranging from 3% at 20 ppm to 17% at 140 ppm. In addition, unlike in dark conditions where an incomplete recovery is observed for Pd/MoS
2
, visible light illumination at room temperature can facilitate the sensor to return to its initial background response when it is exposed to air (
Figure
5
a). It is not uncommon that the recovery of a given gas sensor is often incomplete and very slow at room temperature owing to the strong adsorption of the targeted gas on the sensor surface, leading to unreliable sensing output.
(39)
Therefore, the full recovery of Pd/MoS
2
is very meaningful in terms of practical sensing applications. We also investigated the hydrogen-sensing performance of Pd/MoS
2
at a higher temperature (100 °C) to validate the effect of visible light illumination on the sensing responsivity (
Figure
5
b). As observed, under visible light Pd/MoS
2
is very sensitive to hydrogen with responses ranging from 20% at 20 ppm to 80% at 140 ppm, which are significantly higher than those in dark light (4% at 20 ppm to 21% at 140 ppm). The plot of the sensor response versus hydrogen concentration for Pd/MoS
2
(
Figure
5
c) shows a linear correlation between the gas concentration and sensor response. The sensor sensitivity in visible light is estimated to be 0.123 (% ppm
–1
) at 25 °C and 0.495 (% ppm
–1
) at 100 °C, which is three-fold higher than those measured in the dark at the respective temperatures (0.049 (%ppm
–1
) at 25 °C and 0.154 (% ppm
–1
) at 100 °C). These data unambiguously reveal the visible light enhancement effect toward hydrogen-sensing performance, mainly stemming from the formation of heterojunctions on Pd/MoS
2
. The sensor also shows excellent repeatability with a very small variation in the sensing signal, that is, the sensor response for 140 ppm hydrogen at 25 °C under light illumination is 17.45 ± 1.02% (
Figure
5
d). The response and recovery time of Pd/MoS
2
toward 120 ppm of H
2
at 25 and 100 °C under light radiation were also examined (
Figure S8
). At 25 °C, the response and recovery times calculated as the time required to reach 90% of the saturation value and 90% under the saturation value, respectively, are 351 and 515 s (
Figure S8a
). However, as temperature increases to 100 °C, the sensor shows much faster response and recovery time of 47 and 128 s, respectively (
Figure S8b
). The faster response and recovery of Pd/MoS
2
is mainly attributed to the temperature effect that induces diffusivity (fast response) or desorption (fast recovery) of hydrogen molecules. However, for the gas sensing performance of Pd/MoS
2
particularly at 25 °C, we observed that the sensing signal takes a significantly long time to reach saturation or to recover completely, therefore we fixed the measurement condition for all samples at 25 °C, in which samples were all subjected to hydrogen exposure for 60 s. We also tested the hydrogen gas sensing of bare MoS
2
in the dark and light conditions; however, we could not distinguish noise and sensing signal particularly in the dark. This is because MoS
2
acts as a light sensitizer, rather than the hydrogen-sensitive phase, as indicated by the nonresponsivity toward hydrogen of the bare MoS
2
under visible light irradiation (
Figure
5
e and
Figure S9
). The data are highly consistent with previous reports in which MoS
2
is known to be nonsensitive to nonpolar gases such as hydrogen.
(17,40)
The hydrogen selectivity of Pd/MoS
2
over other gases (C
2
H
5
OH and CH
4
) was also studied, and the data reveal that Pd/MoS
2
showed low responsivity toward C
2
H
5
OH and CH
4
(
Figure S10a
). Further, the stability of Pd/MoS
2
was investigated by measuring the response for the same concentration of hydrogen (120 ppm) for a period of time. As seen in
Figure S10b
, the sensing output was relatively consistent over 6 days. We also examined the sensing response of Pd/MoS
2
at varying relative humidity (RH) (30%, 50%, and 80%) for 120 ppm of H
2
(
Figure S11
). The responsivity was found to decrease with increasing RH level, presumably attributed to the passivation caused by water vapor.

div.p:
Figure 5. Sensing performance of Pd/MoS
2
under dark and light conditions at (a) 25 °C and (b) 100 °C. (c) Plots of the response versus hydrogen concentration. (d) Comparison with pristine MoS
2
under light conditions. (e) Sensing performance after eight cycles. (f) Sensing mechanism of Pd/MoS
2
under light conditions.

div.div:
The principle of the chemiresistive gas-sensing mechanism is based on the electrical resistance/current variations, which are quantitatively correlated with the chemical-sensing reactions occurring at the interface between the target gas and sensor surface.
(41)
Hydrogen, a reducing gas, can donate electrons upon adsorption onto the sensor surface. The transferred electrons lead to either an increase or decrease in the electrical resistance depending on the type of semiconductor used (n- or p-type, respectively).
(16,39,42−48)
In general, MoS
2
synthesized via other techniques, for example, physical vapor deposition (PVD), has low crystallinity and is prone to edge oxidation, resulting in p-type behavior in MoS
2
.
(49)
Meanwhile, the CVD-grown MoS
2
with a high crystallinity usually shows n-type behavior. In this study, we found that no significant defect or decreasing crystallinity of Pd/MoS
2
were observed as evidenced by the low A
1g
/E
1
2g
intensity ratio mapping (
Figure S12
);
(20)
however, the experimental resistance responsivity was observed to increase upon exposure to hydrogen, suggesting that Pd/MoS
2
would have increasing p-type behavior. Also, the valence band structure of Mo 4d (
Figure S4
) reveals that the Fermi level of Pd/MoS
2
was found to move relatively closer to the valence band maximum (VBM) in comparison with bare MoS
2
.
(50,51)
On the basis of these data, we speculate that the deposition of Pd nanoclusters on MoS
2
could result in a p-type behavior of the composite Pd/MoS
2
without scarifying the sample crystallinity. In addition, the reactions of the chemisorbed oxygen species on the sensor surface, which are also important for understanding the gas-sensing mechanism, are schematically shown in
Figure
5
f and
eqs 2
,
3
, and
4
.
(16,39,48)
(2)
(3)
(4)
As hydrogen is purged into the testing chamber, the sensor surface possessing numerous Pd nanoclusters provides more energetically favorable adsorption sites for the hydrogen molecules (
eq 5
). The adsorbed hydrogen molecules are then dissociated into atoms (
eq 6
) and react with the chemisorbed oxygen species (O
–
or O
2–
) (
eqs 7
,
8
). These reactions (
eqs 7
or
8
) provide electrons to the sensor. These electrons eventually combine with holes and hence reduce the charge carrier concentration, leading to an increase in the resistance in the form of a quantitative sensing signal proportional to the concentration of hydrogen gas. Herein, the strong affinity of noble metallic nanoclusters is helpful for the mitigation of the chemisorbed gaseous species in close proximity to initiate their chemical reactions.
(16,39,46)
(5)
(6)
(7)
(8)
Importantly, the formation of Schottky junctions in Pd/MoS
2
evidenced by a nonlinear behavior of the corresponding
I
–
V
curve effectively suppresses the recombination of visible light-generated electron–hole pairs, leading to rapid charge transfer processes that are beneficial for reactions between the chemisorbed oxygen and hydrogen species on the sensor surface. This accounts for the enhanced sensing performance of Pd/MoS
2
. In addition, the use of visible light irradiation is also helpful for reducing the background resistance which in turn amplifies the sensing responsivity when there is a small change in the carrier concentration of MoS
2
due to hydrogen chemisorption. To our knowledge, this is the first example to demonstrate the heterostructuring of Pd nanoclusters and monolayer MoS
2
as an effective strategy to take advantage of light-induced hydrogen gas sensing at room temperature.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We have successfully fabricated heterostructures composed of monolayer MoS
2
and Pd nanoclusters functioning as photo- and hydrogen-sensitizers in a facile and reproducible manner. The Pd/MoS
2
heterostructure as an active hydrogen-sensing layer enables the utilization of visible light for enhancing the sensing performance three-fold relative to dark conditions. Visible light radiation can also improve the sensing reversibility and reproducibility in the obtained sensor. This proof-of-concept opens a new avenue for visible light-induced hydrogen gas sensing at room temperature.

A review. Being a clean source of energy, hydrogen gas is in high demand in various industrial and com. applications. However, the explosive nature of H2 gas >4% concn. makes it highly dangerous to store, transport and use. Further, the small size gas mols. of H2 are prone to leak through the smallest possible holes and cracks. Hence, the detection of H2 gas becomes essential even at trace levels. This article reviews various gas sensing strategies including methods, materials, and integrated systems available for the sensitive detection of H2 gas for a bunch of different applications. The article also reviews some approaches which are available in the literature to detect ppb level of H2 gas concns. This review article aims at explaining the different aspects of H2 gas sensing technol. in a simple yet exhaustive manner.

Semiconducting SnO2 nanowires deposited with Pd and Sn nanoparticles on their surface are a highly sensitive H2 sensor with fast response time at room temp. Compared with the SnO2 nanowire deposited with Pd or Sn nanoparticles alone, the Pd/Sn-deposited SnO2 nanowire exhibits a significant improvement in the sensitivity and reversibility of sensing H2 gas in the air at room temp. The authors' study indicates that two factors are responsible for the synergistic effect of Pd/Sn codeposition on SnO2 nanowires. One is that in the presence of Pd the oxidn. of Sn nanoparticles on the surface of the SnO2 nanowire is incomplete leading only to suboxides SnOx (1 ≤ x < 2), and the other is that the surface of the Pd/Sn-deposited SnO2 nanowire is almost perfectly hydrophobic.

With the exhaustion of traditional energy, increasing attention was paid on the new energy resources like H2. Because of its inflammable and explosive properties, it is imperative and challenging to detect ppm-level H2 during the transport and use process. This paper firstly introduces the working principles and sensing mechanism of the hydrogen sensors based on noble metal doped metal-oxide semiconductors. Then, this paper focuses on the advancement of noble metal doped metal oxide hydrogen sensors, esp. the room temp. hydrogen sensors, in the recent years. At the end, probably fabricating semiconductors with special morphologies, using two different noble metals for bimetallic doping or composite semiconductors with 2-dimensional nanomaterials like graphene/MoS2 to improve the room temp. sensing properties towards low H2 concn. should be the emphasis for the future work.

SnO2-coated ZnO nanorods on c-plane sapphire substrates were synthesized by pulsed laser deposition. The thickness of the polycryst. SnO2 was ∼10 nm, as detd. by high-resoln. TEM, while the diam. of the ZnO nanorods was ∼30 nm. The sensitivity of the SnO2/ZnO structures to H was tested by depositing Ti/Au ohmic contacts on a random array of the nanorods and measuring the current at fixed voltage. There was no response to 500 ppm H2 in N2 at room temp., but the authors obtained a sensitivity of ∼70% at 400°. The SnO2/ZnO structures exhibit drift in their recovery characteristics and for sequential detection of H, as generally reported for SnO2 thin film sensors.

Visible-light photocatalysis enhanced room-temperature formaldehyde gas sensing by MoS2/rGO hybrids
Wang, Jing; Deng, Hanyue; Li, Xian; Yang, Cheng; Xia, Yi
Sensors and Actuators, B: Chemical

The development of high-performance gas sensors operating at room temp. based on transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) remains a challenge. Herein, we demonstrated a novel visible-light photocatalysis-enhanced gas sensor based on MoS2/rGO hybrid, enabling high-performance detection of formaldehyde at room temp. By introducing visible-light illumination, the sensor response to 10 ppm HCHO was increased by over 8 times, and the response time sharply decreased from 79 s to 17 s. The sensor also had advantages of low detection limit, excellent reversibility and long-term stability. The visible-light induced oxygen activation and formaldehyde oxidn. over the MoS2 photocatalysts were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS), O2 temp. programmed desorption anal. (O2-TPD) and in-situ Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (in-situ IR). The enhanced room-temp. HCHO sensing by the MoS2/rGO hybrid was connected with the visible-light photocatalytic activity of MoS2 as well as the efficient charge sepn. rendered by rGO. As a proof-of-concept, the photocatalytic gas sensing approach described here should be a promising strategy for developing room-temp.-operated, high-performance gas sensors based on TMD and other novel semiconductors.

UV-Activated MoS2 Based Fast and Reversible NO2 Sensor at Room Temperature
Kumar, Rahul; Goel, Neeraj; Kumar, Mahesh
ACS Sensors
(
2017

Two-dimensional materials have gained considerable attention in chem. sensing owing to their naturally high surface-to-vol. ratio. However, the poor response time and incomplete recovery at room temp. restrict their application in high-performance practical gas sensors. Herein, we demonstrate ultrafast detection and reversible MoS2 gas sensor at room temp. The sensor's performance is investigated to NO2 at room temp., under thermal and photo energy. Incomplete recovery and high response time of ∼249 s of sensor are obsd. at room temp. Thermal energy is enough to complete recovery, but it is at the expense of sensitivity. Further, under photoexcitation, MoS2 exhibits an enhancement in sensitivity with ultrafast response time of ∼29 s and excellent recovery to NO2 (100 ppm) at room temp. This significant improvement in sensitivity (∼30%) and response time (∼88%) is attributed to the charge perturbation on the surface of the sensing layer in the context of NO2/MoS2 interaction under optical illumination. Moreover, the sensor shows reliable selectivity toward NO2 against various other gases. These unprecedented results reveal the potential of 2D MoS2 to develop a low power portable gas sensor.

The lower gas sensitivity, humidity dependence of the gas sensing properties, and long recovery times of room-temp. gas sensors severely limit their applications. Herein, to address these issues, a series of 3D inverse opal (IO) In2O3-ZnO heterogeneous composite microspheres (HCMs) are fabricated by ultrasonic spray pyrolysis (USP) employing self-assembled sulfonated polystyrene (S-PS) spheres as a sacrificial template. The 3D IO In2O3-ZnO HCMs possess highly ordered 3D inverse opal structures and bimodal (meso-scale and macro-scale) pores, which can provide large accessible surface areas and rapid mass transfer, resulting in enhanced gas sensing characteristics. Furthermore, the 3D IO architecture and n-n heterojunctions can extend the photoabsorption range to the visible light area, effectively prolonging the lifetimes of photo-generated charge carriers, and can increase sepn. of visible light-generated charges. As a result, the as-prepd. 3D IO In2O3-ZnO HCMs deliver excellent NO2 sensing performance under visible light irradn. at room temp., such as high sensitivity (Rgas/Rair = 54.3 to 5 ppm NO2), low detection limit (250 ppb), fast recovery time (188 s), excellent selectivity and humidity independence.

In2O3-sensitized flowerlike ZnO with visible light photoelec. response properties were synthesized by a facile two-step process, and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), SEM (SEM), EDAX, HRTEM and UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The results revealed that In2O3 nanoparticles have grown and eventually coalesced on the surface of the flowerlike ZnO successfully, and the samples exhibited significant response to visible light. The photoelec. gas-sensing of the In2O3-sensitized ZnO was also studied to formaldehyde (HCHO) under 460 nm light irradn. at room temp. with the help of surface photocurrent technique. ZnO sensitized with In2O3 could enhance the gas response to HCHO under the visible light illumination. This may be due to the fact that the composite structure of In2O3-ZnO extends the photo absorbing range to visible light area, inhibits the recombination of photo-generated electrons and holes, and thus increases the utilization of photo-generated carriers in photoelec. gas detection, resulting in the higher sensing response in some extent. The gas response to 5 ppm and 100 ppm formaldehyde can reach to 19% and 419% under visible light irradn. at room temp., resp. These results should be valuable for designing a new type of visible-light assisted gas sensor at room temp.

A review presenting a comprehensive summary of recent progress in gas sensors with advanced heterostructures based on two-dimensional (2D) nanostructured materials is given. The fundamental sensing mechanisms of different types of gas sensors are discussed, and key device architectures and their performance are summarized. Challenges and prospects for future development of each gas sensor type are addressed to promote better sensing-device architectures. Topics discussed include: introduction; gas sensing mechanism (Schottky junction, p-n or n-p junctions, n-n or p-p junctions); performance parameters; gas sensing with 2D nanomaterial-based heterostructures (2D-0D, 2D-1D, 2D-2D, and 2D-3D heterostructures); and summary and perspectives.

During the last decade, two-dimensional materials (2DMs) have attracted great attention due to their unique chem. and phys. properties, which make them appealing platforms for diverse applications in opto-electronic devices, energy generation and storage, and sensing. Among their various extraordinary properties, 2DMs possess high surface area-to-vol. ratios and ultra-high surface sensitivity to the environment, which are key characteristics for applications in chem. sensing. Furthermore, 2DMs' superior elec. and optical properties, combined with their excellent mech. characteristics such as robustness and flexibility, make these materials ideal components for the fabrication of a new generation of high-performance chem. sensors. Depending on the specific device, 2DMs can be tailored to interact with various chem. species at the non-covalent level, making them powerful platforms for fabricating devices exhibiting a high sensitivity towards detection of various analytes including gases, ions and small biomols. Here, we will review the most enlightening recent advances in the field of chem. sensors based on atomically-thin 2DMs and we will discuss the opportunities and the challenges towards the realization of novel hybrid materials and sensing devices.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a typical layered transition-metal dichalcogenide material, which has aroused a great deal of interest in the past few years. Recently, more and more attention has been focused on the synthesis and applications of MoS2-based nanocomposites. In this review, we aimed to present a wider view of the synthesis of various MoS2-based nanocomposites for sensor and biosensor applications. We highlighted the potential methods like self-assembly, hydrothermal reaction, chem. vapor deposition, electrospinning, as well as microwave and laser beam treatments for the successful prepn. of MoS2-based nanocomposites. On the other hand, three representative types of detection devices fabricated by the MoS2-based nanocomposites, field-effect transistor, optical, and electrochem. sensors, were introduced in detail and discussed fully. The relationships between the sensing performances and the special nanostructures within the MoS2-based nanocomposites were presented and discussed.

A highly sensitive hydrogen gas sensor composed of an MoS2-Pt nanoparticle thin film as the active layer is introduced. The sensor achieved ultra-fast response and recovery rates of 4 s and 19 s, resp., for 100 ppm of H2. The MoS2-Pt composite film exhibits a high sensor response (R1/R2) of 10 when exposed to 100 ppm of H2 gas, which outperforms the existing metal sulfide- based sensors. The stability of the device over a period of 70 days and the selectivity of the device is outstanding. A plausible mechanism for the MoS2-Pt based H2 gas sensor is discussed. Furthermore, the sensitivity, response and recovery rates for various concns. of H2 gas are studied. The sensor response is exceptionally promising. This sensor with metal sulfide-platinum composite active layers can be applied in the sensor field to amplify the sensing performance.

A facile, scalable and low-cost strategy for fabricating hydrogen sensors with few-layered Pd-functionalized MoS2 according to a simple soln. process is reported. The sensors were prepd. by drop-casting a MoS2-contg. soln. onto a SiO2 substrate and functionalizing the surface of the MoS2 with Pd using evapn. Patterned deposition of Cr/Au on top of the MoS2-coated SiO2 substrate was then performed using evapn. through a shadow mask to place the micro electrodes on the substrate. The fabricated Pd-MoS2 sensors successfully detected hydrogen gas dild. by air at room temp. With exposure to hydrogen gas, the Pd was converted to palladium hydride, which has a lower work function than MoS2, resulting in the transfer of electrons from palladium hydride to MoS2, thereby decreasing the resistance of the sensor. The functionalized MoS2 showed a 35.3% resistance change when exposed to a 1% hydrogen-contg. gas, while the pristine MoS2 showed no reaction. The lower limit of detection of the resulting functionalized MoS2 sensor was 50 ppm.

Over the past decade, the field of two-dimensional (2D) layered materials has surged, promising a new platform for studying diverse phys. phenomena that are scientifically intriguing and technol. relevant. Contacts are the communication links between these 2D materials and the three-dimensional world for probing and harnessing their exquisite electronic properties. However, fundamental challenges related to contacts often limit the ultimate performance and potential of 2D materials and devices. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the basic understanding and importance of contacts to 2D materials and various strategies for engineering and improving them. In particular, we elucidate the phenomenon of Fermi level pinning at the metal/2D contact interface, the Schottky vs. Ohmic nature of the contacts and various contact engineering approaches including interlayer contacts, phase engineered contacts, and basal vs. edge plane contacts, among others. Finally, we also discuss some of the relatively under-addressed and unresolved issues, such as contact scaling, and conclude with a future outlook.

The sulfur vacancy (Sv) generation in the MoS2 basal plane is an efficient strategy for improving the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). By using cationic current treatment, the Sv d. can be controlled by modifying the setting voltage ranges and treatment time. The Sv generation mechanism was clearly defined using Raman mapping. From the Raman mapping characterizations, for the first time, it is exptl. found that Sv tends to be generated next to existing Sv by appearing around cracked/damaged areas or group formations. The S: Mo at. ratio reduced from 2.02:1-1.86:1 after treatment. As a result, the c.d. at -0.3 V vs. RHE sharply increases up to 27-fold in comparison to that with untreated MoS2, and the overpotential of treated MoS2 reaches 222 mV at 10 mA/cm2 with a Tafel slope of 96 mV/decade. Hence, the controllable Sv generation in monolayer MoS2 using a cationic current method can be considered as a fast, simple, and effective process to improve HER performance in large-scale prodn.

Recently, many literatures report on the excellent performance of MoS2-based NO2 sensing, however, lacking the study on its thermal stability. Here, the insight mechanism in NO2 sensor reactivity of monolayer MoS2 at different temps. from 25 to 200°C was investigated. The relative effect of the morphol. properties of the sensor and gas sensor reactivity at different temps. was obsd. using in situ Raman mapping, optical microscope, and scanning electron microscope to demonstrate the mechanism of temp.-dependent limit of NO2 detection in ppb. By increasing the temp. from 25 to 100°C, the response of the sensor significantly improves (4.8% vs. 54.4%) at 200 ppb, and its limit of NO2 detection strongly decreases (48.0 vs. 6.9 ppb). Interestingly, the sensor performance from 100 to 150°C is likely equiv. to a limit of detection (LoD) that varies from 8.1 to 6.9 ppb, and the LoD slightly increases to 15.0 ppb at 200°C. The line damages were found in monolayer MoS2 basal plane by heating the sample up to 200°C, that affect to the recovery of the NO2 sensor. This study reveals an effective approach that may be useful in developing a gas sensor with a high response and limit of NO2 detection in the ppb scale.

The surface oxidn. of palladium nanocrystals plays an important role in changing the active sites and subsequently influencing the catalytic reactivity. Such a microscopy study on surface oxidn., down to the at. scale, is essential for understanding the structure-property correlations of palladium nanocrystal based catalysts. Herein, we present an in situ at. scale study on the surface oxidn. behavior of palladium nanocrystals, which is induced by electron beam irradn. under low oxygen partial pressure and at room temp. inside an environmental transmission electron microscope. We found that: (i) surface oxidn. initially started at the edge sites with at. steps or vertex sites, which served as active sites for oxidn.; (ii) the oxidn. reaction proceeded with a much faster rate on the {111} surface, indicating a certain crystallog. preference; (iii) nanometer-sized palladium monoxide islands were formed on the surfaces eventually. The results from our in situ studies provide insightful knowledge, and will be of certain importance for the design of improved functional catalysts in future.

To achieve sustainable prodn. of H2 at ambient temp., highly active and stable electrocatalysts are the key to water splitting technol. commercialization for hydrogen and oxygen prodn. to replace Pt and IrO2 catalysts. Herein, a modified interface of palladium (Pd) and reduced graphene oxide (RGO)-supported molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) prepd. by the solvothermal followed by chem. redn. method is established, in which abundant interfaces are formed. The phase structure, compn., chem. coupling, and morphol. of the two-dimensional nanostructures are established by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, XPS, and transmission electron microscopy, resp. A structural phase transformation in MoS2 is obsd. from trigonal (2H) to octahedral (1T) by virtue of Pd addn., which is well established from XRD, Raman, and XPS studies. For oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the RGO/MoS2/Pd (RMoS2Pd) catalyst exhibits extremely low overpotential (245 mV for OER and 86 mV for HER) to achieve benchmark c.d., with small values of Tafel slope (42 mV dec-1 for OER and 35.9 mV dec-1 for HER) and charge transfer resistance. The quant. study shows the hydrogen prodn. rate of RMoS2Pd of 335 μmol h-1 with excellent stability in alk. medium, which is superior to MoS2, RMoS2, and MoS2Pd. The improved performance of RMoS2Pd is attributed to the combined synergetic effect of 1T MoS2, sulfur vacancy, and conducting RGO sheet, which efficiently accelerate the overall electrochem. water splitting.

Nanoscale transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMDC) materials, such as MoS2, exhibit promising behavior in next-generation electronics and energy-storage devices. TMDCs have a highly anisotropic crystal structure, with edge sites and basal planes exhibiting different structural, chem., and electronic properties. In virtually all applications, two-dimensional or bulk TMDCs must be interfaced with other materials (such as elec. contacts in a transistor). The presence of edge sites vs. basal planes (i.e., the crystallog. orientation of the TMDC) could influence the chem. and electronic properties of these solid-state interfaces, but such effects are not well understood. Here, we use in situ XPS to investigate how the crystallog. and structure of MoS2 influence chem. transformations at solid-state interfaces with various other materials. MoS2 materials with controllably aligned crystal structures (horizontal vs. vertical orientation of basal planes) were fabricated, and in situ XPS was carried out by sputter-depositing three different materials (Li, Ge, and Ag) onto MoS2 within an XPS instrument while periodically collecting photoelectron spectra; these deposited materials are of interest due to their application in electronic devices or energy storage. The results showed that Li reacts readily with both crystallog. orientations of MoS2 to form metallic Mo and Li2S, while Ag showed very little chem. or electronic interaction with either type of MoS2. In contrast, Ge showed significant chem. interactions with MoS2 basal planes, but only minor chem. changes were obsd. when Ge contacted MoS2 edge sites. These findings have implications for electronic transport and band alignment at these interfaces, which is of significant interest for a variety of applications.

A simple and versatile method is described for growing highly anisotropic nanostructures of Pd, single-crystal nanobars bounded by {100} facets and single-crystal nanorods with their side surfaces enclosed by {100} and {110} facets. According to thermodn. arguments, Pd atoms should nucleate and grow in a soln. phase to form cuboctahedrons of spherical shape with their surfaces bounded by a mix of {111} and {100} facets. Anisotropic nanostructures can only form under kinetically controlled conditions, while the cubic symmetry is broken. In the present system, one-dimensional growth could be induced and maintained through an interplay of (1) rapid redn. of the precursor to insure prompt addn. of atoms to the seed (2) chemisorption of bromide on the seed to promote the formation of {100} and {110} facets (3) localized oxidative etching on one specific face of the seed to initiate preferential growth on this face. Exptl., the anisotropic growth can be achieved by varying the type and concn. of reducing agent, as well as by adjusting the reaction temp. The methodol. developed for Pd has also been extended to both Au and Pt. As expected for a kinetically controlled product, the anisotropic nanostructure evolved into the thermodynamically favored shape during an aging process.

We present a novel approach to prep. helical carbon nanofibers homogeneously functionalized with single crystal palladium nanoparticles via a phase-transfer method. The materials were characterized by SEM, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), XPS, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), thermogravimetric anal. (TGA), and electrochem. measurements. We find that homogeneous and small single-crystal Pd nanoparticles can be easily functionalized with Ph mercaptan, transferred into the toluene phase from the DMSO phase and then non-covalently self-assembled onto the surface of helical carbon nanofibers with a very good dispersion and homogeneous diams. of 4.5±0.6 nm. The palladium-helical carbon nanofiber composite exhibits significantly higher electrochem. active area and electrocatalytic activity towards the electrooxidn. of formic acid, ethanol and methanol than the com. electrocatalyst Pd/Vulcan XC-72. Our results show that the prepd. material can be potentially used as an advanced nano-electrocatalyst in a direct alk. fuel cell system.

Noble metals and their oxide nano-clusters are considered to be the most promising candidates for fabricating advanced H2 gas sensors. Through this work, we propose a novel strategy to grow and modulate the d. of PdO/PdO2 nanoparticles uniformly on nanostructured Pd-doped ZnO (ZnO : Pd) films by a one-step soln. approach followed by thermal annealing at 650°C, and thus to detect ppm-level H2 gas in a selective manner. The gas sensing properties of such hybridized materials showed that the PdO-functionalized ZnO samples offer significantly improved H2 gas sensing properties in an operating temp. range of 25-200°C. The deposition of ZnO : Pd films via a simple synthesis from chem. solns. (SCS) approach with an aq. bath (at relatively low temps., <95°C) is reported. Furthermore, the functionalization of palladium oxide nanoclusters by a simple but highly effective approach on ZnO : Pd film surfaces was performed and is reported here for the first time. The morphol., structural, vibrational, optical, chem., and electronic properties were studied in detail and the mixed phases of palladium oxide nanoclusters on the ZnO surface were found. Sensor studies of the ZnO : Pd samples (in the range of 25-350°C operating temp.) showed good selectivity to H2 gas, esp. in the range of higher temps. (>150°C, up to 350°C); however, the PdO/PdO2 mixed phases of the nanocluster-modified surface ZnO : Pd films showed a much better selectivity to H2 gas, even at a lower operating temp., in the range of 25-150°C. For such PdO-functionalized ZnO : Pd films, even at room temp., a gas response of ∼12.7 to 1000 ppm of H2 gas was obtained, without response to any other reducing gases or tested vapors. The large recovery time of the samples at room temps. (>500 s) can be drastically reduced by applying higher bias voltages. Furthermore, we propose and discuss the gas sensing mechanism for these structures in detail. Our study demonstrates that surface functionalization with PdO/PdO2 mixed phase nanoclusters-nanoparticles (NPs) is much more effective than only the Pd doping of nanostructured ZnO films for selective sensing applications. This approach will pave a new way for the controlled functionalization of PdO/PdO2 nanoclusters on ZnO : Pd surfaces to the exact detection of highly explosive H2 gas under various atmospheres by using solid state gas sensors.

The monolayer films were grown with chem. vapor deposition processes and controlled to have an optimal d. (7-10%) of sulfur vacancies. Following this understanding, we enable excellent catalytic activities at the monolayer MoS2 films by using substrates that can provide n-doping to MoS2 and form low interfacial tunneling barriers with MoS2, such as Ti. It is demonstrated that the luminescence efficiency of monolayers composed of MoS2, WS2, and WSe2 is significantly limited by the substrate and can be improved by orders of magnitude through substrate engineering. The substrate affects the efficiency mainly through doping the monolayers and facilitating defect-assisted nonradiative exciton recombinations, while the other substrate effects including straining and dielec. screening play minor roles. The doping may come from the substrate and substrate-borne water moisture, the latter of which is much stronger than the former for MoS2 and WS2 but negligible for WSe2. Using proper substrates such as mica or hexagonal boron nitride can substantially mitigate the doping effect. The defect-assisted recombination depends on the interaction between the defect in the monolayer and the substrate. Suspended monolayers, in which the substrate effects are eliminated, may have efficiency up to 40% at room temps. The result provides useful guidance for the rational design of at.-scale light emission devices.

Controlling the bandstructure through local-strain engineering is an exciting avenue for tailoring optoelectronic properties of materials at the nanoscale. Atomically thin materials are particularly well-suited for this purpose because they can withstand extreme nonhomogeneous deformations before rupture. Here, we study the effect of large localized strain in the electronic bandstructure of atomically thin MoS2. We report resonant Raman scattering of MoS2 layers comprising of single, bi, four and seven layers, showing a strong dependence on the layer thickness. Indirect band gap MoS2 in bulk becomes a direct band gap semiconductor in the monolayer form. New Raman modes are seen in the spectra of single- and few-layer MoS2 samples which are absent in the bulk. The Raman mode at ∼230 cm-1 appears for two, four and seven layers. This mode has been attributed to the longitudinal acoustic phonon branch at the M point (LA(M)) of the Brillouin zone. The mode at ∼179 cm-1 shows asym. character for a few-layer sample. The asymmetry is explained by the dispersion of the LA(M) branch along the Γ-M direction. The most intense spectral region near 455 cm-1 shows a layer-dependent variation of peak positions and relative intensities. The high energy region between 510 and 645 cm-1 is marked by the appearance of prominent new Raman bands, varying in intensity with layer nos. Resonant Raman spectroscopy thus serves as a promising non invasive technique to accurately est. the thickness of MoS2 layers down to a few atoms thick. Copyright © 2012 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Conformal growth of at.-thick semiconductor layers on patterned substrates can boost up the performance of electronic and optoelectronic devices remarkably. However, conformal growth is a very challenging technol. task, since the control of the growth processes requires utmost precision. Herein, we report on conformal growth and characterization of monolayer MoS2 on planar, microrugged, and nanorugged SiO2/Si substrates via metal-org. chem. vapor deposition. The continuous and conformal nature of monolayer MoS2 on the rugged surface was verified by high-resoln. transmission electron microscopy. Strain effects were examd. by photoluminescence (PL) and Raman spectroscopy. Interestingly, the photoresponsivity (∼254.5 mA/W) of as-grown MoS2 on the nanorugged substrate was 59 times larger than that of the planar sample (4.3 mA/W) under a small applied bias of 0.1 V. This value is record high when compared with all previous MoS2-based photocurrent generation under low or zero bias. Such enhancement in the photoresponsivity arises from a large active area for light-matter interaction and local strain for PL quenching, wherein the latter effect is the key factor and unique in the conformally grown monolayer on the nanorugged surface.

Two dimensional (2D) materials with a monolayer of atoms represent an ultimate control of material dimension in the vertical direction. Molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) monolayers, with a direct bandgap of 1.8 eV, offer an unprecedented prospect of miniaturizing semiconductor science and technol. down to a truly at. scale. Recent studies have indeed demonstrated the promise of 2D MoS2 in fields including field effect transistors, low power switches, optoelectronics and spintronics. However, device development with 2D MoS2 has been delayed by the lack of capabilities to produce large-area, uniform and high-quality MoS2 monolayers. Here we present a self-limiting approach that can grow high quality monolayer and few-layer MoS2 films over an area of centimeters with unprecedented uniformity and controllability. This approach is compatible with the std. fabrication process in semiconductor industry. It paves the way for the development of practical devices with 2D MoS2 and opens up new avenues for fundamental research.

The influence of uniaxial tensile mech. strain in the range 0-2.2% on the phonon spectra and band structures of monolayer and bilayer MoS2 2-dimensional crystals are reported. First, Raman spectra were used to observe phonon softening with increased strain, breaking the degeneracy in the E' Raman mode of MoS2, and ext. a Grueneisen parameter of ∼1.06. Second, using luminescence a decrease in the optical band gap of MoS2 was measured that is approx. linear with strain, ∼45 meV/% strain for monolayer MoS2 and ∼120 meV/% strain for bilayer MoS2. Third, a pronounced strain-induced decrease in the luminescence intensity of monolayer MoS2 was obsd. that is indicative of the direct-to-indirect transition of the character of the optical band gap of this material at applied strain of ∼1%. These observations constitute a demonstration of strain engineering the band structure in the emergent class of 2-dimensional crystals, transition metal dichalcogenides.

In this work, we demonstrate that the incorporation of MoS2 nanosheets with Pd nanodots is a promising way for promoting the visible-light-induced Suzuki-Miyaura C-C coupling reaction. The MoS2 nanosheets decorated with Pd nanodots showed very high photocatalytic activity. The turnover frequency for the biphenyl product was >1600 h-1 even under sunlight illumination at room temp. A review. Hydrogen has captured a lot of attention in recent years because its abundance, cleanness and one of the most promising sources of green energy. However, hydrogen has an explosive nature. Accordingly, detection of hydrogen leaks is important from a safety point of view. In this review paper, we use numerous examples to explain how Pd-decoration on the surfaces of nanomaterials can lead to enhancements in response and selectivity toward hydrogen gas. First, we describe the importance of hydrogen detection, then the properties of Pd and PdHx are reviewed, and metallic Pd hydrogen gas sensors are discussed. Finally, we comprehensively review different semiconducting gas sensors decorated with Pd with more emphasis on the sensing mechanism. This review paper provides a simple yet informative background for researchers working in this hot field.

Two-dimensional materials such as graphene show great potential for future nanoscale electronic devices. The high surface-to-vol. ratio is a natural asset for applications such as chem. sensing, where perturbations to the surface resulting in charge redistribution are readily manifested in the transport characteristics. Single monolayer MoS2 functions effectively as a chem. sensor, exhibiting highly selective reactivity to a range of analytes and providing sensitive transduction of transient surface physisorption events to the conductance of the monolayer channel. Strong response upon exposure to triethylamine, a decompn. product of the V-series nerve gas agents were found. These results in the context of analyte/sensor interaction in which the analyte serves as either an electron donor or acceptor, producing a temporary charge perturbation of the sensor material are discussed. Highly selective response to electron donors and little response to electron acceptors, consistent with the weak n-type character of the authors' MoS2 were found. The MoS2 sensor exhibits a much higher selectivity than carbon nanotube-based sensors.

A review. With increasing attention on hydrogen (H2) produced by renewable energy methods for transport and other applications, an updated evaluation of H2 monitoring techniques is timely. The emergence of nanomaterials with unique properties enables a new class of H2 sensing materials, exhibiting important attributes such as high surface area to vol. ratio, reactivity and no. of active sites. The development of these materials allows for improved H2 sensing methods with increased sensitivity, selectivity, speed and improved economy for both financial cost and power consumption. These advances enable small-scale, high-performance H2 sensors for use in emerging hybrid renewable energy systems, including Internet of Things (IoT) or mobile systems. While literature reports on H2 sensors include thermal cond., resistive, optical, acoustic, electrochem. and catalytic methods, this review will focus on resistive H2 sensing nanomaterials. Three classes of these nanomaterials are discussed: metal oxides, transition metal dichalcogenides, and graphene based nanomaterials. As a key aim of this review is improved economy of use, the authors will elaborate only sensors operating at temps. <200°, with a focus on potential for room temp. operation.

We report enhanced sensing properties of Pd-coated SnO2 nanorod (NR) arrays for detecting H2 gas in N2 and dissolved in transformer oil. The Pd nanoparticles were coated on randomly ordered vertical SnO2 NR arrays by the glancing angle deposition (GLAD) method, which utilizes an electron-beam evaporator and a DC magnetron sputtering system. The Pd-coated SnO2 NR arrays exhibited high response (104 at 1% H2) in N2. Pd-coated SnO2 NR arrays were immersed and in mineral oil that contains various concns. of dissolved H2 and the elec. response was measured. We found that the Pd-coated SnO2 NR arrays showed superior response (R = ∼96), low detection limit (0.3 ppm), and fast response times (300 s). The Pd-coated SnO2 NR arrays had a temp. coeff. of resistance (TCR) of 3.69 × 10-3°C-1 at various oil temps. (20-80°C), indicating good thermal stability at high temps. The sensing mechanism of the Pd-coated SnO2 NR arrays was also demonstrated by using changes in the Schottky barrier height at the Pd/SnO2 interface upon exposure to H2.

Atm. pollution is one of the major aspects of concern which led to the research of sensors for the detection of toxic gases. The supreme surface-to-vol. ratio makes two-dimensional MoS2 a promising material to be used as an electronic sensor. Here, we demonstrate the fabrication of a high-performance gas sensor based on at.-layered MoS2 nanoflakes synthesized by a facile hydrothermal process. Structural and morphol. studies confirmed the formation of few-layered phase pure hexagonal MoS2 nanoflakes. The results demonstrate that the Pd-MoS2 layers exhibited a very high relative response to NO gas (700%) at 2 ppm concn. with a min. NO detection limit of 0.1 ppm and Ni-MoS2 demonstrated a relative response of 80% towards H2S gas with a limit of detection of 0.3 ppm with good repeatability and selectivity, owing to the increased adsorption energy of NO on Pd-MoS2 and H2S on Ni-MoS2 through the formation of PdNOx and NiS2 complexes resp. The improved sensing performance of this MoS2-based sensor also suggests the great potential and possibility of MoS2 related 2D materials and its combinations for the development of futuristic highly sensitive nanosized gas sensors suitable for anti-pollution automotive system and as volatile biomarkers.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has emerged as a promising material for the development of efficient sensors. Here, we have exfoliated and decorated MoS2 flakes with the novel, single-phase multi-component silver-gold-copper-palladium-platinum (Ag-Au-Cu-Pd-Pt) alloy nanoparticles, popularly named High Entropy Alloy (HEA) nanoparticles, using facile and scalable low-temp. grinding, followed by the sonochem. method. It was found that the decoration of HEA nanoparticles imparts the surface-enhanced Raman scattering effect and redn. in the work function of the material from 4.9 to 4.75 eV as measured by UPS. This change in the work function resulted in a Schottky barrier between the gold contact and HEA decorated MoS2 flakes as a result of drastic changes in the surface chem. non-stoichiometry. The response to hydrogen gas was studied at temps. in the range of 30 to 100 °C, and it showed an unusual p-type nature due to surface-adsorbed oxygen species. The nanoscale junction formed between HEA and MoS2 showed a ten-time increase in the response towards hydrogen gas at 80 °C. The exptl. observations have been explained with DFT simulation showing more favorable hydrogen adsorption on HEA-decorated MoS2 resulting in an enhanced response.

In this work, the important role of electronic changes taking place at the palladium (Pd)-graphene interface during hydrogen sensing has been established by studying hydrogen sensing behavior of Pd and Pd/graphene composite layers with different Pd thicknesses. CVD-grown single layer graphene and Pd nanoparticulate layers deposited by thermal evapn. method were used in this study. A drastic change in hydrogen sensing behavior was obsd. in Pd/graphene samples as the topog. of Pd layer changes from a continuous film to a discontinuous nanoparticulate layer and finally to isolated Pd nanoparticles. In case of Pd nanoparticles/graphene samples having isolated nanoparticles, the obsd. sensing behavior is due to change in electronic nature of Pd/graphene interface on hydrogen exposure. Relatively lower value of work function of palladium hydride in comparison to graphene results in electron migration and compensation of p-type charge carriers in graphene on hydrogenation of Pd. The hole doping at Pd-G interface is also confirmed by Raman spectroscopy. The Pd/graphene interface sensor with 10 nm of Pd thickness shows enhanced sensing response (at 2% hydrogen) of 51.4% with faster response time (6 s) in comparison to sensing response (41%) and response time (56 s) in Pd thin film sensor having similar thickness.

Heterojunction based gas sensor was fabricated by forming two semiconductor nanostructures interface i.e. n-type ZnO nanorods and p-type NiO nanoplates. These nanostructures were synthesized via chem. routes. Palladium (Pd) nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized and sensitized on the surface of heterojunction sensor material to enhance the gas response. Sensor materials were characterized using XRD, TEM, FESEM, EDS, Elemental mapping, and XPS techniques for their physicochem. properties. The n-ZnO/p-NiO heterojunction sensors with and without Pd NPs sensitization were investigated for low hydrogen gas concn. 2-100 ppm. Pd NPs sensitized n-ZnO/p-NiO heterojunction sensor showed higher response of 72% towards 100 ppm hydrogen (H2) gas concn. at the operating temp. 225 °C, whereas 53% response was noted by p-NiO/n-ZnO heterojunction sensor for 100 ppm concn. at 237 °C operating temp. Both the sensors were investigated for selectivity studies using methane (CH4), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon dioxide (CO2) and H2 gases. Higher selectivity was obsd. towards H2 gas for both the sensors. The gas responses of both sensors were investigated at various operating temps. and concns. Transient response, repeatability, and stability were also confirmed for both sensors. The gas sensing mechanism for heterojunction sensors was elucidated.

MoS2, as a model transition metal dichalcogenide, is viewed as a potential channel material in future nanoelectronic and optoelectronic devices. Minimizing the contact resistance of the metal/MoS2 junction is crit. to realizing the potential of MoS2-based devices. The Schottky barrier height (SBH) and the band structure of high work function Pd metal on MoS2 were studied by in situ XPS. The anal. spot diam. of the XPS spectrometer is ∼400 μm, and the XPS signal is proportional to the detection area, so the influence of defect-mediated parallel conduction paths on the SBH does not affect the measurement. The charge redistribution by Pd on MoS2 is detected by XPS characterization, which gives insight into metal contact physics to MoS2 and suggests that interface engineering is necessary to lower the contact resistance for the future generation electronic applications.

Protonic Titanate Nanotube-Reduced Graphene Oxide Composites for Hydrogen Sensing
Yadav, Shubham; Nair, Archa; Urs MB, Kusuma; Kamble, Vinayak B.

H sensors are of tremendous technol. demand, which requires more selective and responsive sensors over a wide concn. range (ppm to percentage). Here, the authors report a giant enhancement in sensor performance in diffusion-limited H response of protonic titanate nanotubes (TNTs, H2Ti3O7) by the addn. of reduced graphene oxide (RGO). Unlike TiO2, the elec. cond. of TNTs decreases upon heating up to ∼120° due to the loss of chem. adsorbed H2O, which imparts protonic conduction <100°. Thus, TNTs are very sensitive and selective to H gas due to protonic conduction. However, their response kinetics is dominated by slow diffusion of H, leading to large response times (~ 1000 s for 1000 ppm). An ex situ fabricated sensor using a TNT-RGO phys. hybrid exhibits a gigantic 950% change in current upon exposure to 1000 ppm H gas at 30° with half the response time of nearly 200 s, whereas the phase-sepd. TNT-RGO composite made in situ shows 1.5 times enhancement and a further lower response time of ~ 40 s without losing the selectivity offered by pristine nanotubes. The dynamic range as well as the response time of the titanate nanotubes is improved due to I heterostructure formation at the interface of TNTs and RGO as seen from XPS. The sensor response shows 2 distinct time consts. in both response and recovery, depicting the 2 processes involved, which is also confirmed by impedance spectroscopy. The bulk diffusion-dominated TNTs and surface-dominated RGO along with their heterostructures are identified as key factors for enhanced sensor properties, particularly faster satn. and recovery. In paper, the authors not only have made composites and phys. hybrids but show that effective mixing is necessary to achieve better sensing properties.

A review. Being a clean source of energy, hydrogen gas is in high demand in various industrial and com. applications. However, the explosive nature of H2 gas >4% concn. makes it highly dangerous to store, transport and use. Further, the small size gas mols. of H2 are prone to leak through the smallest possible holes and cracks. Hence, the detection of H2 gas becomes essential even at trace levels. This article reviews various gas sensing strategies including methods, materials, and integrated systems available for the sensitive detection of H2 gas for a bunch of different applications. The article also reviews some approaches which are available in the literature to detect ppb level of H2 gas concns. This review article aims at explaining the different aspects of H2 gas sensing technol. in a simple yet exhaustive manner.

Semiconducting SnO2 nanowires deposited with Pd and Sn nanoparticles on their surface are a highly sensitive H2 sensor with fast response time at room temp. Compared with the SnO2 nanowire deposited with Pd or Sn nanoparticles alone, the Pd/Sn-deposited SnO2 nanowire exhibits a significant improvement in the sensitivity and reversibility of sensing H2 gas in the air at room temp. The authors' study indicates that two factors are responsible for the synergistic effect of Pd/Sn codeposition on SnO2 nanowires. One is that in the presence of Pd the oxidn. of Sn nanoparticles on the surface of the SnO2 nanowire is incomplete leading only to suboxides SnOx (1 ≤ x < 2), and the other is that the surface of the Pd/Sn-deposited SnO2 nanowire is almost perfectly hydrophobic.

With the exhaustion of traditional energy, increasing attention was paid on the new energy resources like H2. Because of its inflammable and explosive properties, it is imperative and challenging to detect ppm-level H2 during the transport and use process. This paper firstly introduces the working principles and sensing mechanism of the hydrogen sensors based on noble metal doped metal-oxide semiconductors. Then, this paper focuses on the advancement of noble metal doped metal oxide hydrogen sensors, esp. the room temp. hydrogen sensors, in the recent years. At the end, probably fabricating semiconductors with special morphologies, using two different noble metals for bimetallic doping or composite semiconductors with 2-dimensional nanomaterials like graphene/MoS2 to improve the room temp. sensing properties towards low H2 concn. should be the emphasis for the future work.
